title: Multilevel mHealth Intervention Increases Physical Activity of Older Adults Living in Retirement Community
abstract: Background: Regular physical activity is crucial for healthy aging, but older adults are the least active age group. This study explored the feasibility, acceptability, and efficacy of a multilevel mHealth intervention for increasing physical activity of older adults living in a retirement community Methods: Participants included 54 older adults (mean age = 81.2 y, 77.8% female, 98.1% white) living in a retirement community. Participants received a Fitbit Zip and access to a multilevel mHealth physical activity intervention (MapTrek Residential) for 8 weeks. Physical activity (in steps per day) and intervention compliance (days worn) were measured objectively with the Fitbit for 12 weeks (8-wk intervention plus 4-wk follow-up). Psychosocial outcomes

sections.title: Background
sections.text:
Older adults (≥65 y) represent a large and growing segment of the US population.  1  Engaging in regular physical activity is a crucial component of healthy aging as it confers many health benefits including improved cognitive function, physical function, and quality of life.  2, 3 The Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans recommend older adults achieve at least 150 minutes per week of moderate-intensity aerobic activity and minimize the amount of time spent sitting during the day. Importantly, the guidelines also stress that the greatest health benefits are achieved for those who are most sedentary and that replacing sitting with even light-intensity walking can be beneficial.  3 Still, older adults are the least active age group;  4  only 16.3% of those aged 65-75 years are sufficiently active.  5 der adults report multilevel barriers to increasing activity, including lack of safe environments to be active, reluctance to exercise alone, financial constraints, and low self-efficacy for physical activity.  6, 7 Conversely, multiple studies and systematic reviews of physical activity interventions for community-dwelling older adults have identified multilevel facilitators of physical activity including access to convenient and enjoyable activities and receipt of social and environmental supports for physical activity.  [8] [9] 10] With a growing number of older adults living in continuing care retirement communities (CCRCs), and evidence suggesting multilevel interventions are more effective than interventions targeted at the individual level alone, this represents an ideal setting for developing physical activity interventions targeted to older adults. To date, few physical activity interventions have been conducted among older adults living in CCRCs.

Recently, the ubiquity of mobile computing devices and the low cost of physical activity monitors (eg, Fitbits) have dramatically increased the feasibility of delivering multilevel physical activity interventions within the retirement community setting. Our team recently developed an mHealth physical activity intervention called MapTrek for the purpose of promoting physical activity using a low-cost, scalable platform.  11 MapTrek was originally designed as a mobile phone-based walking game that places participants into a series of virtual, individual walking races for the purpose of encouraging more daily physical activity throughout the day. We recently demonstrated that MapTrek significantly increased physical activity behaviors of sedentary office workers over 10 weeks.11 Given the past success of MapTrek, we decided to adapt MapTrek for use among older adults living in CCRCs. MapTrek was redesigned for older adults living in CCRCs by removing the phone requirement (as many older adults do not have smartphones) and creating a team-based format.

The purpose of this study was to test the efficacy and acceptability of an 8-week multilevel mHealth intervention for increasing physical activity of older adults living in a CCRC in a phase IIa proof of concept trial.  12 Based on our previous study, testing our mHealth intervention among sedentary office workers,  11  we hypothesized participants would immediately increase their physical activity from baseline to week 1 and that physical activity levels would remain elevated throughout the 8-week intervention. We hypothesized participants would maintain their elevated activity levels after the intervention was removed for 4 weeks. Finally, we hypothesized participants would increase their social support for physical activity, self-efficacy for physical activity, outcome expectations for physical activity, and social isolation from baseline to 8 weeks.

sections.title: Participants
sections.text:
We recruited a convenience sample of older adults (≥ 65 years) living at a single CCRC in a Midwestern state. Participants were recruited from June 17, 2019 to June 27, 2019, by word of mouth and through advertisements posted on digital monitors located throughout the CCRC. Eligibility of the participants was contingent upon their full-time residence at the CCRC, ability to walk without a walker, and an ability to wear a Fitbit activity monitor daily throughout the intervention. Exclusion criteria included: (1) age <65 years; (2) not fluent in English; and (3) any reported contraindications to engaging in physical activity. Interested participants were invited to attend a large group-based orientation session in which our team explained the study in detail. After all questions were answered, eligible and interested participants provided their voluntary informed consent. A total of 54 participants were found to be eligible and enrolled in the study.

After providing their consent to participate, participants were asked to complete a baseline survey which asked about their demographic information and included several psychosocial questionnaires.13-15 Each participant was then provided with a Fitbit activity monitor and oriented on how to properly wear and use the device to self-monitor their daily activity. Participants were then asked to wear the Fitbit for a minimum of 7 days to assess their baseline physical activity. Following the baseline testing period, participants were invited to attend a large group orientation session during which participants were provided further details about the intervention.

sections.title: MapTrek Intervention
sections.text:
Immediately following the orientation session, participants received access to the MapTrek intervention. MapTrek was designed to be a fun and interactive game to motivate participants to increase their daily physical activity behavior (walking). Key components of the intervention included a wearable Fitbit activity monitor that each participant received and wore daily throughout the intervention,  3  TV monitors placed in common areas (eg, main lobby, café, activity room) throughout the CCRC which illustrated the MapTrek game board, and 5 sync stations placed near the TV monitors which automatically synced participant's Fitbit monitors to the MapTrek operating system. The sync stations were controlled with small (credit card-sized) Raspberry Pi computers that had Bluetooth capability for syncing with Fitbits. Participants were instructed to walk near the sync stations daily to ensure their Fitbit steps would be added to the team total. The syncing process took roughly 1 minute to complete.

All TV monitors presented the same information which included: (a1) the walking route of the current race, (b2) a Google Maps Street View illustrating the leading team's location on the map at any given time, (c3) a team leaderboard that reported total team steps and team places, and (d4) daily educational and motivational messages designed to target specific theoretical constructs including self-efficacy and outcome expectancies (Figure  1A ). A new walking route/race was launched every 2 weeks. To foster social support for physical activity and reduce social isolation, participants were assigned to one of 3 teams and provided a wrist band for their team (black, white, or teal). The 3 teams competed against each other in the 2-week races. Steps recorded from each participant's Fitbit were added to the team step total and each team's logo automatically progressed along the walking route based on team steps. Participants were encouraged to walk to a TV monitor and sync station daily to ensure their steps were added to the team total, to keep up on the status of the races, to view the leader board, and to read the daily educational/motivational messages. The daily messages were developed by PhD level members of the research team and were based on demonstrated behavior change techniques informed by the social cognitive theory.  16 The daily messages were updated each day at 7:00 AM.

Consistent with the social-ecological model,  17  MapTrek was designed to target known determinants of physical activity that operate at multiple levels. At the individual level, new educational messages were displayed each day on the TV monitors to improve attitudes, knowledge, beliefs, self-efficacy, and outcome expectations regarding physical activity. Specifically, messages focused on the known benefits of physical activity, the negative consequences of physical inactivity, tips for improving physical activity, and positive/encouraging messages. Each individual was also provided a Fitbit activity monitor to support individual self-monitoring of daily steps. At the social level, it was our intention that the teambased approach would promote social support, build self-efficacy through peer modeling, and potentially reduce social isolation. Each team was comprised of both residents and staff members with the intent of establishing a supportive culture of physical activity within the CCRC environment. At the end of the 8-week intervention, all participants were asked to complete a follow-up survey which repeated questions asked at baseline on self-efficacy for exercise,  13  social support for exercise,  14  outcome expectations for exercise,  15  and social isolation  18  (described in detail in the Measures section). Participants were also asked to complete a process evaluation survey which asked questions about satisfaction with the intervention. At the end of the process evaluation survey, participants were asked to continue wearing their Fitbit monitors for an additional 4-week follow-up period. The purpose of the follow-up period was to determine whether physical activity levels were maintained following removal of the mHealth intervention. MapTrek display monitors were deactivated during the 4-week follow-up period.

sections.title: Measures
sections.text:
Physical Activity.-The primary outcome for the study was steps per day as measured objectively with the Fitbit Zip, a small (35.6 × 28.9 × 9.6 mm) commercially available tri-axial accelerometer-based physical activity monitor that estimates steps taken per day. The Fitbit Zip has been demonstrated as a valid and reliable measure of daily steps among community-dwelling older adults compared with the ActiGraph GT3X+ (intraclass correlation coefficient = .94, 95% CI, 0.88 to 0.97).  19 At the beginning of the study, all participants were provided a Fitbit Zip activity monitor and were asked to wear the monitor on the nondominant wrist, during all wakeful hours, each day through the duration of the intervention. Minute-by-minute level step data were downloaded using the Fitbit application programming interface. Participants' compliance wearing the Fitbit was determined by counting the number of days each participant successfully recorded Fitbit-measured steps.

Psychosocial Outcomes.-The secondary psychosocial outcomes were assessed with 4 questionnaires. Self-efficacy was measured with the Self-Efficacy for Exercise scale, a 13-item questionnaire designed to assess participants' self-efficacy related to their ability to continue exercising in the face of barriers.  13 Social support for physical activity was measured with a modified version of the Social Support and Exercise Survey. The Social Support and Exercise Survey is a 12-item (originally 13 item) questionnaire that assesses the level of support from family and friends that participants have in making health behavior changes (exercise).  14 Outcome expectations were measured with the Outcome Expectations for Exercise Scale. The Outcome Expectations for Exercise is a valid and reliable 9-item scale that assesses the participant's outcome expectations and benefits associated with exercise.  15 Social isolation was measured with a modified version of the Friendship Scale. The Friendship Scale is a 5-item (originally 6-item) scale that assesses 6 dimensions contributing to social isolation.  18

sections.title: Engagement and Satisfaction
sections.text:
To assess the acceptability of the intervention, we measured participants' engagement and satisfaction with the intervention. Engagement was estimated by objectively tracking the number of days participants successfully wore the Fitbit activity monitor. To measure overall satisfaction with the intervention, participants completed a process evaluation survey during week 8. In the survey, participants were asked to rate (5-point Likert scale; [strongly disagree] to [strongly agree]) their experience with the intervention (eg, MapTrek was fun, MapTrek was easy to play, MapTrek motivated me to be more active, I was able to play MapTrek in my spare time, I felt more supported to be active due to having access to MapTrek, I would like to continue having access to MapTrek, MapTrek motivated me to keep wearing my Fitbit). Participants also rated (5-point Likert Scale; [not at all helpful] to [very helpful]) the helpfulness of each intervention feature (eg, game route, images from Google Street View, leaderboard, educational information, team-based approach).

Finally, participants were invited to participate in one of 3 focus groups to provide openended feedback on the intervention features they found to be most and least helpful, suggestions for improving the intervention, barriers they experienced that limited their participation, and any unexpected benefits to participating in the intervention. Focus groups were semi-structured and held in person at the CCRC. A total of 18 participants participated in the focus groups. Each group included between 4 and 8 participants and lasted between 20 and 40 minutes.

sections.title: Statistical Analysis
sections.text:
All statistical analyses were completed using SAS (version 9.4; Cary, NC). P values of <.05 were considered statistically significant. Descriptive statistics (ie, mean, SD, frequency) were calculated for participant characteristic including age, sex, height, weight, and BMI. A total of 54 residents and 14 staff members were enrolled in the study. Only the residents' physical activity data were used in the analysis.

In order to test the effect of the intervention on physical activity, linear mixed models examined changes in steps per day from study baseline (week 0) to the end of the active intervention (week 8), and follow-up period (week 12). In addition, linear mixed models were utilized to examine the changes in steps per day from baseline (week 0) to the initial start of the active intervention (week 1), and from the end of the active intervention (week 8) to the end of the follow-up period (week 12). Intervention week was entered as the independent variable, and steps per day were entered as dependent variables. A post hoc Tukey test was used to test between-week differences (in steps per day). To test the relationship between changes (Δ) in psychosocial outcomes and changes (Δ) in physical activity, correlations and simple linea regressions were used.

Paired t tests were used to test for differences in mean scores for self-efficacy, social support, outcome expectations, and social isolation from baseline to the end of the active intervention (week 8). To examine the association between changes (Δ) in psychosocial outcomes and changes (Δ) in physical activity, correlations and simple linear regressions were used.

Descriptive statistics (ie, mean, SD, frequency) using SAS (version 9.4) and qualitative analysis were used to analyze acceptability outcomes from the process evaluation. Focus groups were transcribed by a single research team member. Transcriptions were independently examined for key, overarching themes by 2 investigators. Both investigators independently read and coded the exit surveys and met to compare themes to determine if they shared similar data interpretations. Themes were then defined as more than 2 people responding similarly to a question.  20

sections.title: Results
sections.text: A total of 68 (54 residents and 14 staff) participants enrolled in the study and completed baseline testing. Of these participants, 52 (42 residents and 9 staff) completed follow-up testing at 12 weeks. Baseline characteristics of the 54 residents initially enrolled are displayed in Table  1 . Briefly, participants were older (81.2 [5.5] y), mostly female (77.8%), white (98.1%), and college-educated (94.4%). More than half were married (51.9%) and earned more than $75,000 annually (59.3%). The average length of stay at the retirement community among participants was 5.0 (4.7) years with 66% living at the retirement community between 1 and 5 years.

sections.title: Physical Activity
sections.text: Participants walked an average of 5438 (95% CI, 4620 to 6256) steps per day at baseline. During the first week of the intervention, participants significantly increased their daily step average to 6681 (95% CI, 5840 to 7522) steps per day (P < .0001). Participants remained significantly more active compared with baseline during all weeks of the intervention except for week 7 (+340 steps per day, P = .07). At week 8, participants were still more active compared with baseline (+763 steps per day, P < .0001). Over the course of the 4 week, postintervention follow-up period, participants remained significantly more active compared with baseline during week 9 (+771 steps per day, P < .0001) and week 10 (+508 steps per day, P = .01) but not during week 11 (+147, P = .44) or week 12 (-20 steps per day, P = .92; see Figure  2 ).

sections.title: Psychosocial Outcomes
sections.text:
Summative scores for self-efficacy for exercise (0-90 scale) decreased from baseline (73.2 [14.1]) to postintervention (67.4 [15.2]; P = .02), indicating lower self-efficacy at the end of the active intervention. When exploring individual questionnaire items, participants reported significant decreases in items asking about exercising if they were busy with other activities (P = .01), when they felt tired (P = .03), and when they felt depressed (P = .01). No correlation between change in self-efficacy and change in physical activity was observed (r = -.09; P = .60).

Social support for exercise did not change from baseline (2.2 [0.7]) to postintervention (2.2 [0.8], P = .90). When exploring individual questionnaire items, significant decreases were observed for friends, family, and/or staff at the retirement community: "exercised with me" (P = .04) and "offered to exercise with me" (P = .04). No correlation between change in social support and change in physical activity was found (r = -.28; P = .06).

Outcome expectations for exercise did not change from baseline (4.4 [0.6]) to postintervention (4.4 [0.6]; P = .45). No correlation was observed between change in outcome expectations and change in physical activity (r = -.07; P = .70). Social isolation (0-20) did not change from baseline (17.9 [2.4]) to postintervention (17.6 [2.7]; P = .40). When exploring individual questionnaire items for social isolation, no changes were observed. However, when examining the additional social isolation question scores, there was a significant increase for "I joined a new activity" (P = .001). No correlation was observed between change in social isolation and change in physical activity (r = -.15; P = .3; see Table  2 ).

sections.title: Engagement and Satisfaction
sections.text:
Participants wore the Fitbit activity monitors on 82% of all days during the baseline period, 92% of all days during the 8-week intervention period, and 84% of all days during the 4-week followup period. Cumulatively, out of 4214 possible wear days, participants wore the Fitbit 3726 days (88% compliance rate).

A total of 43 participants completed the postintervention process evaluation survey. The majority of participants reported they either agreed or strongly agreed that MapTrek was easy to play (76.7%), MapTrek motivated them to keep wearing their Fitbit (65.1%), they were able to play MapTrek in their spare time (65.1%), they thought MapTrek was fun (55.9%), and they felt MapTrek supported them to be more active (53.5%; Figure  3 ). When asked about the helpfulness of specific intervention features, participants reported "displaying the leaderboard," "displaying daily information and education," and "displaying the game route" as most helpful for increasing their daily physical activity (Figure  4 ).

When exploring the qualitative open-ended responses from focus group for "most helpful features," the most frequently reported features were "having the Fitbit," followed by the "team/competition aspect" and "being able to see their team's steps on the TV monitor." Among the least helpful features, the most frequently reported comments were "the lack of feedback when syncing Fitbits," "the map and display board," the "Google Street View image," and "not knowing who was on their team." The most common reported barriers to participating in the intervention included "pain," "injury," and "other health issues," followed by "traveling" and "lack of motivation." The most frequently reported unexpected benefits to participation included "having more social and discussion opportunities," "becoming more motivated to walk and exercise," "an increased awareness of their own physical activity," "feeling like they were a part of something," "meeting someone new," and "feeling better after walking." The most common suggestions participants provided for improving MapTrek were "to update the sync stations so that they notify participants when the Fitbit syncs," "having team meet-ups and activities" to support socialization, and "receiving more feedback on individual steps."

sections.title: Discussion
sections.text:
The results of this pilot study indicate that a multilevel mHealth intervention increased physical activity among older adults living in a CCRC over the short term. Over the course of the 8-week intervention, participants walked an average of 6266 steps per day, representing a 15% increase compared with the baseline period. However, once the MapTrek intervention was removed (monitors disabled), participants' physical activity levels regressed back to their baseline levels. At 12 weeks, participants returned to walking an average of 5417 steps per day, which was similar to the 5438 steps they were walking at baseline. In addition, while participants were asked to continue wearing and syncing their Fitbit each day during the follow-up period, Fitbit compliance dropped by 12% to 84% compliance during the follow-up period. This finding is consistent with our process evaluation data in which 65% of participants reported MapTrek motivated them to keep wearing their Fitbit. Collectively, these findings suggest MapTrek had a positive short-term effect on participants' physical activity levels and that participants found the intervention engaging while it was operational. However, these findings also suggest that both physical activity levels and compliance dropped once the intervention was removed. It may be difficult for residents to maintain their elevated physical activity levels with just a Fitbit and no additional support from the intervention team. Future technologybased physical activity interventions like MapTrek should be designed to be user friendly so that they can continue to be administered by nonresearch staff. In this specific case, members of the CCRC staff could be trained on how to administer MapTrek challenges and should be evaluated for effectiveness over a longer duration.

In order to provide additional context for these findings, it is important to consider the typical activity levels of older adults. Past studies have found heathy older adults tend to walk anywhere between 2000 and 9000 steps per day (median of 5500 steps per day).  21 articipants of the present study were averaging 5438 steps per day at baseline and would therefore be considered approximately as active as the average older adult. However, over the course of the intervention, participants were walking more than the median steps for older adults. It has been recommended that healthy older adults walk between 7000 and 10,000 steps per day, which would be equivalent to accumulating 30 minutes of daily MVPA and meeting the recommendations put forth by the Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans.  21 Collectively, participants of this intervention averaged fewer than 7000 steps per day. Our findings are consistent with previous physical activity interventions targeting older adults living within CCRCs. Rosenberg et al  22  found both a standard walking intervention and enhanced walking intervention lead to increased daily step counts of roughly 500 steps per day (10-15% increase), which is consistent with the relative increase in physical activity observed in our study (+15%).

Our findings are also consistent with a study by Strath et al,  23  which examined the feasibility of combining a pedometer with step targets and motivational messages for increasing physical activity among older adults.  24 Participants increased their daily steps by more than 40%, which is far greater than the 15% increase we observed in our study.

Contrary to our hypotheses, we did not observe improvements in self-efficacy for exercise or outcome expectations over the 8-week intervention. Given participants' high levels of self-efficacy and outcome expectations at baseline, a ceiling effect may have limited any significant increase in these variables. It is possible participants were overly optimistic about their perceived ability to exercise in certain situations, which has been reported in previous studies.  25 A second explanation for the observed decline in selfefficacy could be that participants did not engage with the TV monitors. Specifically, behavior change techniques designed to increase self-efficacy may not have been delivered as they were intended. Intervention features designed to increase self-efficacy included adding motivational and educational information on the bottom of the display monitor. Although the messages were displayed, some participants reported not looking at the monitors because they could sync at a syncing station without a monitor. Other participants reported not seeing the messages, which may have been due to how small the daily message section was on the monitor. With regards to outcome expectations, participants in this study were highly educated and therefore may have been more aware of the physical and psychological benefits of physical activity than most older adults. Previous research has found a positive association between education level and knowledge about the benefits of physical activity.  26 Still, it is also possible the intervention did not effectively target self-efficacy and/or outcome expectations as intended.

We also did not observe an improvement in social support over the course of the intervention. While we attempted to facilitate social support by taking a team approach and placing staff members on each team as "team leaders," only 16% of participants reported this feature to be helpful. Given evidence suggesting social support from friends has a stronger influence on physical activity habits of older adults than social support received from family and/or experts,  27  future interventions should consider testing the efficacy of peer leaders as opposed to staff members.

We did not observe a decrease in social isolation among participants over the 8-week intervention. Participants entered the study reporting low levels of isolation, which left little room for improvement. Such low levels of isolation could be a testament to the CCRC where this study was conducted, which offers regular socializing events. This finding could also be due to a self-selection bias as residents who are more socially isolated may have been less likely to enroll in the study.

This study was limited by the use of a single-arm study design that included a relatively small sample size. Our use of the Fitbit activity monitor as an outcome measure, as opposed to a blinded, research-grade accelerometer, limits the overall accuracy of the physical activity data. We also recruited a convenience sample of older adults living in a local retirement community. The sample was a homogenous group of participants who were mostly white, mostly female, highly educated, and of middle to upper income levels. It is unclear if the study findings can be generalized to older men, older adults with lower income and education, and/or older adults from racial and ethnic minority groups. However, the present study should be viewed as a phase IIa "proof of concept study" as defined by the ORBIT model.  12 Based on the ORBIT model, the next step for this line of research would be to test MapTrek in a phase IIb pilot study, which compares MapTrek against a control group among a more representative sample. Future studies should include a more diverse sample and possibly target CCRCs located in rural areas where facilities may offer fewer social events and opportunities for physical activity.

Although the study did have limitations, this study had many strengths as well. First, MapTrek is an innovative platform that leverages multiple technologies (Fitbit activity monitors, Raspberry Pi computers, and TV display monitors) to deliver a multilevel intervention to increase physical activity levels of older adults living full time in a retirement community. MapTrek combines individual level behavior change techniques (eg, providing educational/motivational information, encouraging self-monitoring) with social level behavior change techniques (eg, team-based approach) to support the physical activity behavior change process. Second, we were able to objectively measure participants' physical activity patterns on a granular level over the course of the intervention. Given our early stage of development for this intervention, this data provided us a clear picture of the immediate and long-term effects of the intervention, which we will use to further refine and improve MapTrek. Finally, MapTrek was designed so that it could be scaled to reach larger numbers of participants and delivered to older adults who are at greater risk for physical inactivity including older adults living in rural areas who have limited access to physical activity resources.

sections.title: Acknowledgments:
sections.text: The authors thank our participants for their contributions to this study. The authors thank  Justin Perez  for his contribution to the study. This research was funded by  ICTS Pilot Grant Program for Clinical and Translational Studies . The authors declare no conflict of interest.

sections.title: Conclusions
sections.text: These data suggest our multilevel mHealth physical activity intervention significantly improved physical activity levels among a sample of older adults residing in a CCRC over 8 weeks but that physical activity levels were not maintained once the intervention was removed. Participants found the intervention to be acceptable, but many refinements are warranted. Additional studies that test the efficacy of a refined version of the intervention against control group in a phase IIB pilot study are needed.
